content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: really nice quick programming thinking and solving a nice problem that every developer should be able to solve under 5 minutes
It's interesting, but it shouldn't be into Clash code sections. I'd like to move it to Puzzles

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Bonne explication, permet de travaillé l'informatique et des connaissances en Math !

A bit too trivial in languages where this is built in. My suggestion is to change the problem to one where the elements are divided into three groups a b c, where a + b + c = n. Then you'd need to calculate n! / (a! b! c!)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

couldn't u just use math.comb in python? really unfair for languages that don't have a built in function or library for shortest mode

also i dont think the first 2 sentences in the statement are needed

I really enjoyed solving this problem using Dart. The concept of calculating combinations is always interesting, and the constraints made it manageable and fun. It was a nice exercise in using factorials and understanding how combinations work in practice.

One suggestion to improve the problem would be to clarify the input/output format a bit more. Also, it would be great to add more examples with edge cases, like when  k=0 or k=n, just to make sure all possibilities are covered. Overall, I had a great time solving it!

Goal
* Please change "Combinations is combinations in which" to "For combinations".

* You are calculating the number of combinations; you are not calculating combinations themselves. And you haven't mentioned anything about what [[n]] and [[k]] are. Please change "Combinations can" to "The number of combinations for choosing [[k]] elements from [[n]] elements can".

* Please format the formula properly by using the multi-line monospace syntax (adding three backticks ``` before and after the block of text).

* Please change "an integers" to "two integers".

Thanks.
